    Daniel Watkins

    Climate scientist at Brown University. Chronic dabbler.

    • Bluesky
    • Instagram

    Vitae

    Daniel M. Watkins

    Senior Research Associate
    Center for Fluid Mechanics
    Brown University, Providence, RI

    Education

    PhD Ocean, Earth, and Atmospheric Sciences, Oregon State University (2022)

    • Thesis: Vertical structure of the lower troposphere in a changing Arctic
    • Advisor: Jennifer Hutchings

    MS Mathematics, Drexel University (2015)

    • Advisor: Gideon Simpson

    BS Applied Mathematics, Brigham Young University—Idaho (2013)

    Research Experience

    Senior Research Associate, Wilhelmus Lab, Center for Fluid Mechanics, Brown University, Providence, RI (Oct 2023-Present)

    Postdoctoral Research Associate, Wilhelmus Lab, Center for Fluid Mechanics, Brown University, Providence, RI (July 2022-2023)

    Research Internships:

    • Graduate Student, Risk Analysis and Decision Support, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM (2014)
    • National Security Internship Program, Applied Statistics and Computational Modeling, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA (2013)
    • Department of Homeland Security Visiting Student, Risk Analysis and Decision Support, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM (2012)

    Field Experience

    • Multidisciplinary drifting Observatory for the Study of Arctic Climate (MOSAiC) Expedition, Akademik Fedorov (Sept-Oct 2019)
    • Field course on ocean observing and experiment design, R/V Oceanus (2 weeks, May 2016)

    Publications

    1. Ahmed, Fox-Kemper, Watkins, Wexler, and Wilhelmus (2025) “Estuarine Temperature Variability: Integrating Four Decades of Remote Sensing Observations and In-Situ Sea Surface Measurements,” Remote Sensing of Environment, 322, 113543. doi: 10.1016/j.rse.2025.114643
    2. Watkins, Persson, Stanton, and others (2024) “Air-Ice-Ocean Coupling During a Strong Mid-Winter Cyclone: Observing Coupled Dynamic Interactions Across Scales,” Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres, e2024JD041057. doi: 10.1029/2024JD041057
    3. Rabe and others (2024) “MOSAiC Distributed Network: observing the coupled Arctic system with multidisciplinary, coordinated platforms,” Elementa: Science of the Anthropocene 12 (1): 00103. doi: 10.1525/elementa.2023.00103
    4. Watkins, Bliss, Hutchings, and Wilhelmus (2023) “Evidence of abrupt transitions between sea ice dynamical regimes in the East Greenland marginal ice zone,” Geophysical Research Letters. Vol. 50, e2023GL103558. doi: 10.1029/2023GL103558
    5. Bliss, Hutchings, and Watkins (2023) “Sea ice drift tracks from autonomous buoys in the MOSAiC Distributed Network,” Scientific Data, 10, 403 (2023). doi: 10.1038/s41597-023-02311-y
    6. von Albedyll, Hendricks, and others (2022) “Thermodynamic and dynamic contributions to seasonal Arctic sea ice thickness distributions from airborne observations,” Elementa: Science of the Anthropocene. Vol. 10, Issue 1, Apr. 2022. doi: 10.1525/elementa.2021.00074
    7. Nicolaus, Perovich, Spreen, and others (2022) “Overview of the MOSAiC expedition: Snow and sea ice,” Elementa: Science of the Anthropocene. Vol. 10, Issue 1, Feb. 2022. doi: 10.1525/elementa.2021.000046
    8. Krumpen, Birrien, Kauker, and others (2020) “The MOSAiC ice floe: sediment-laden survivor from the Siberian shelf”, The Cryosphere, 14, 2173–2187, doi: 10.5194/tc-14-2173-2020
    9. Simpson and Watkins (2019) “Relative entropy minimization over Hilbert spaces via Robbins-Monro.” AIMS Mathematics, 4(3): 359-383. doi: 10.3934/math.2019.3.359 Article
    10. Watkins, Cuéllar, Kubicek, Rodriguez, and Stroud (2015) “Identifying Security Checkpoint Locations to Protect the Major US Urban Areas.” Homeland Security Affairs, Vol. 11, Sept. 2015, Article
    11. Watkins, Sego, Holmes and others (2013), “Assessing performance and tradeoffs of bioforensic signature systems,” 2013 IEEE International Conference on Technologies for Homeland Security (HST), Waltham, MA, USA, pp. 304-309, doi: 10.1109/THS.2013.6699019

    Preprints and (recent) conference presentations

    1. Watkins, Buckley, Kim, Hutchings, and Wilhelmus (2025) “Characterizing the Marginal Ice Zone in the Greenland Sea Through Seasonal Floe-Scale Sea Ice Observations,” submitted to Journal of Glaciology. Preprint
    2. Watkins, Hutchings, and Wilhelmus (2025) “Assessing interannual variability in the marginal ice zone,” AMS Polar Meteorology and Oceanography (AMS Denver Summit), Denver, CO, May 2025 Poster
    3. Watkins, Buckley, Kim, and Wilhelmus (2024) “Observing floe-size dependent sea ice dynamics in the Fram Strait marginal ice zone,” AGU Fall Meeting, Washington, DC, December 2024. Poster
    4. Watkins, Persson, Hutchings, Stanton, Solomon, Bliss, Ahmed, and Wilhelmus (2024) “Sea ice dynamical response to cyclones at moderate and large scales,” MOSAiC 3rd International Science Conference, Potsdam, Germany, February 2024
    5. Watkins, Buckley, Kim, and Wilhelmus (2023) “Ice Floe Tracker: An Open-Source Tool Enabling Novel Observations of Sea Ice Motion from Visual Remote Sensing Imagery,” AGU Fall Meeting, San Francisco, CA, December 2023 Poster
    6. Watkins, Persson, Hutchings, Stanton, and Solomon (2023) “Sea Ice and Ocean Response to a Strong Mid-Winter Cyclone in the Arctic Ocean,” AGU Fall Meeting, San Francisco, CA, December 2023, Poster

    4. Watkins (2023), “Air-ice-ocean coupled interactions during a strong winter cyclone”, APOG Seminar, Brown University, Providence, RI, Oct. 25, 2023
    5. Watkins (2023), “Dynamics of coupled Arctic air-ice-ocean interactions from floe scale to basin scale”, Applied and Computational Mathematics Seminar, Dartmouth College, Hannover, NH, October 10, 2023
    6. Watkins, Wilhelmus, Buckley, and Kim (2023) “Tracking ice floes from space”, NOAA Sea Ice Modeling Workshop, Boulder, CO, April 24-26, 2023
